15.text:
[Sonnet Stanfill] Thank you very much Megan for 
that wonderful introduction. But before I begin,

19.text:
I want to do some further thanking of my own. I'd 
like to acknowledge the collaborative efforts

25.text:
and old fashioned hard work of the team at the 
Frist. I'd like to begin by thanking director

31.text:
Susan Edwards for both her initial interest in the 
project and her successful efforts in bringing

36.text:
on board the other venues which made this US 
tour possible. And these venues were the

42.text:
Minneapolis Institute of Art and the Portland Art 
Museum in Oregon. I'd also like to thank chief

47.text:
curator Mark Scala for his support and curator 
Trinita Kennedy for her unflagging efforts in

53.text:
realizing the exhibition here at the Frist. Thanks 
also go to exhibition designer Hans Schmitt-

59.text:
Matzen, whose attention to detail and 
professionalism resulted in the seamless

64.text:
translation of this project into the Frist's own 
beautiful galleries. Lead technician Scott Thom

71.text:
along with all the members of the installation 
and exhibitions teams ensured the smooth

75.text:
running of so many aspects of this installation. 
I'm also grateful for the contributions of the

80.text:
registrar's team, along with the efforts of 
Marketing Director Kathy Demonbreun

87.text:
and her colleague Wallace Joiner, as well as 
Media & PR Director Buddy Kite. Thank you

92.text:
also again to Megan and to Ginny Soenksen for 
all of their help. And now, we're going to look at

98.text:
some beautiful images about Italian fashion. So 
I'm absolutely delighted that you're all able to

105.text:
give up your Friday evenings to join me here 
tonight. And the aim of this talk is to give you

111.text:
a little sneak peak behind the scenes of what 
you're going to see when you go into the

114.text:
exhibition. But first I'd like to set the exhibition a 
little bit in context and answer the questions

121.text:
of why Italian fashion and why the V&A. So to 
start with I think we have to back many years

128.text:
ago to some Stanfill family trips. As you can 
probably tell from my accent, I am not British

134.text:
even though I work at a British national 
institution. I'm in fact from Alaska.

138.text:
And in order to combat this bad luck [laughter], 
my father and mother made every effort

149.text:
to bring us to Europe at every opportunity. So in 
fact I spent quite a few vacations and holidays

156.text:
on the streets of Rome and Florence and Milan 
noticing the difference between what people

161.text:
wore there and on the streets of Anchorage. 
[Laughter] And so the seed was planted.

168.text:
Helped of course by visits to Italian art 
museums which led to a BA in Art History.

177.text:
And also a Master's degree in the History of 
Fashion. And ever since I received those,

182.text:
that degree in History of Fashion, I have been 
asking myself the question, "Why hasn't there

186.text:
been a major exhibition looking at Italian style?" 
And in fact, there is this surprising feature of

194.text:
the Italian cultural landscape that there is no 
national collection of fashion in Italy.

199.text:
Nor is there a collection of design in a national 
Italian museum. So this gave the V&A a unique

206.text:
opportunity to propose and deliver an exhibition 
devoted to Italian style. The image that you see

214.text:
on the screen for me sums up very nicely the 
sense of joie de vivre and this kind of careless,

222.text:
easy elegance that enfuses so many of the 
designs that you're going to see

225.text:
within the exhibition. It's in fact a photograph 
from 1985 of an advertisement for the Italian

232.text:
designer Gianfranco Ferre, whose work you'll 
also see in the show. And I'd like for you to keep

237.text:
this image in mind as we look at some of the 
further examples within the show.

242.text:
But as the title suggests, we start at the end of 
the second World War. And as this image will

251.text:
convey, Italy, like much of the rest of Europe, 
was both physically and economically

257.text:
devastated at the War's end. It's hard to imagine 
looking at that photograph that in just a few

262.text:
year's time, Italy will become one of the leading 
sources of fashion design in the world.

267.text:
During the War, the Italian government actually 
tried to regulate fashion production.

274.text:
It was necessary of course to limit the use of 
fabrics and materials for the war effort.

280.text:
But they also tried to control what they called a 
sense of "Italian-ness" in design. I'm not quite

286.text:
sure what that meant, but I think Mussolini had 
an idea. And one of the elements that he

292.text:
instituted in this program was something called 
"il marchio di garanzia," the mark of gaurantee,

297.text:
which was a kind of award given to producers of 
garments when they had met his restrictions.

306.text:
And that, you can see a photograph, just to the 
right of one of those marks. And it's a little label

313.text:
that producers could sew into their garments. 
There is in fact one of these marks inside a

320.text:
dress on display as you first enter the galleries. 
It's a very rare surviving example.

325.text:
Because not surprisingly the Italians weren't 
particularly organized in implementing this

330.text:
program. And so very few marks of guarantee 
survive. But we move very quickly on from the

338.text:
war's end to a different moment. A moment when 
glamour exploded on to the international scene.

344.text:
Gowns created by Italian designers. And this is 
a part of the story that I as an American find very

352.text:
interesting, because the North American market 
was crucial for the development of an Italian

357.text:
fashion industry. And in fact the American 
government, through the Marshall Plan, ensured

363.text:
that Italian textile factories were heavily 
subsidized so that they could grow and expand

368.text:
after the war. The United States needed Italy as 
a viable trading partner and they also needed to

375.text:
help Italy rehabilitate its reputation after so 
many years of Fascist rule. And after many

384.text:
weeks of research within several archives in 
Italy, I found documents from the U.S.

390.text:
government that talked directly about promoting 
this nascent fashion industry in Italy.

395.text:
Some of the things I wanted to point out were 
that in fact the first fashion shows that were

402.text:
internationally attended in Italy took place in 
Florence. We often think of Milan now as the

408.text:
fashion capital, but in 1951, one gentleman, Mr. 
Giovanni Battista Giorgini, held the first fashion

417.text:
show in Italy to which international buyers and 
press came. The first fashion show was in his

423.text:
living room. Attended by only a dozen people but 
they were deeply influential and included

429.text:
a member of the press corp of Women's Wear 
Daily, as well as buyers from Bergdorf Goodman

434.text:
and B. Altman, among others. The next event of 
note after the one in Giorgini's house took place

442.text:
in a much larger room. And you'll see a 
photograph of this here, this is the so called

447.text:
Sala Bianca in Palazzo Pitti in Florence just 
south of the Arno. And he secured the use of

453.text:
this glamorous hall through his many 
connections. Before the war he had been a

458.text:
buying agent for U.S. department stores and he 
helped them to import Italian handicrafts.

464.text:
After the war he used all of these connections to 
convince these same people to come

469.text:
to Florence and see these fashion shows. The 
Sala Bianca or White Hall in Palazzo Pitti

476.text:
as you can see from the image is a very 
glamorous room, it's chandelier-bedecked.

480.text:
Those are murano glass chandeliers. It's a very 
very grand space and beautiful back drop

485.text:
against which to show these glamorous gowns. 
And so very quickly the guest list grew, from just

492.text:
a few, a handful really, to several hundred, to by 
1955 over 500 guests came to attend

500.text:
the shows. The thing too that he was able to 
achieve, not only securing the use of this grand

506.text:
hall and convincing buyers and press to come, 
was that he convinced the Italian designers

513.text:
from all across Italy to come to one place and 
show. Because of course there were designers

518.text:
not just in Florence but also in Milan and Rome 
and he was able to get them to look past their

524.text:
regional differences and come to one place to 
show. And this makes me remember the sense

532.text:
of regional suspicion the Italians have, of a 
conversation I had in a taxi cab in Rome

539.text:
where the taxi cab driver was talking about his 
suspicion of the people from Naples

545.text:
and he said, "After I shake the hand of someone 
from Naples I count how many fingers I have."

549.text:
[Laughter] So this is no mean feat on the part of 
Giorgini that he brought everyone to one place.

557.text:
And here you see a photograph of the great man 
himself on the far left and some of the models

562.text:
showcasing designs. But really the thing to 
remember too is that these designs for the most

569.text:
part, they were cocktail dresses and evening 
gowns, but the Italians set themselves apart

574.text:
by showing sportswear. A designer like Pucci for 
example would have shown skiwear and

579.text:
beachwear, amongst some of the gowns by the 
other designers. So they were offering a whole

585.text:
wardrobe that the American market accepted 
readily.

590.text:
I did a lot of the research for this portion of the 
exhibition in this very unassuming looking

596.text:
building. It's the state archives in Florence, 
where the Giorgini papers are held, and it's a

601.text:
fascinating process to gain access to a building 
like this, because it involves not just a lot of

607.text:
paperwork but a lot of coffee drinking with people 
to make sure they think you're okay. [Laughter]

614.text:
And there I discovered documents like this, 
which is one of the guest lists for the 1955 event

623.text:
and I don't know if those of you in the back can 
see but what was so exciting for me was to read

628.text:
some of the names on this list, which include 
the great department stores across

632.text:
the United States. B. Altman, Filene's, Macy's, 
I.Magnin in San Francisco, and many others,

639.text:
as well as the stores across Europe. So what 
we have here is really a who's who's list

645.text:
of the filters of taste for the North American 
market. Because these buyers, now long

651.text:
forgotten, were really the conduits through which 
the choice and style of North American women

658.text:
were created. Just to give you a bit of additional 
context, in this slide you'll see photographs

666.text:
of that very first show in 1951 in Giorgini's living 
room. And you can see that the models are just

673.text:
kind of walking around. A group of women 
seated in chairs. But the photograph on the right

679.text:
shows Giorgini's daughter Matilda with one of 
the buyers from Morgan's department store

685.text:
in Montreal, Henry Nixon. Henry is seated with 
Matilda with a way that suggests that perhaps

692.text:
their alliance is more than just professional. 
[Laughter] And after conversations with

699.text:
the grandson, I can confirm that they had a 
dalliance. But then also one of the programs

707.text:
is shown below. And the thing that Giorgini did 
so creatively was that he ensured that his

713.text:
guests had a fabulous time. There were 
suppers, there were dances, there were all kinds

719.text:
of entertainment. So they were really the kind of 
prototype of what we think of as a fashion week.

726.text:
Catwalk shows interspersed with all sorts of 
other attractions. I mentioned sportswear earlier

733.text:
and here you see a sampling of a Pucci blouse 
on the catwalk and in our conservation studio

739.text:
the same blouse before it went on display. And 
there is John Nixon again with his little bowtie

745.text:
at the background, seated next to Julia Trissel, 
the buyer for Bergdorf Goodman.

749.text:
And you can see that these are designs that 
weren't really always about the hightlest level of

756.text:
couture. There was a sportswear option 
available. We then move on to a part of

762.text:
the exhibition that talks about a different type of 
clothing. This is clothing made for one woman

768.text:
by a dressmaker. A dressmaker in Italy is called 
a sartoria. A sartoria has a kind of lower level

776.text:
if you like of a reputation. She probably doesn't 
have a designer label in her garments.

781.text:
She has a small atelier of seamstresses and 
she's servicing a very local clientele

787.text:
who develop a relationship with her over the 
years and who trust her to create wardrobes

792.text:
that are both stylish but also adapted to the 
client's figure and taste. In this case, the client

800.text:
is Mrs. Werner Abegg. There's a photo of her on 
the left. By all reports she was a woman of good

805.text:
humor and she also had very specific ideas 
about how she wanted to dress.

812.text:
She was married to the textile and art collector 
Werner Abegg who also had a cotton finishing

819.text:
plant in Turin where they lived. Mrs. Abegg could 
have afforded the best of French couture.

825.text:
But she chose to buy local and she went to the 
dressmaker Maria Grimaldi to have her suits and

832.text:
evening gowns made. And here is a detail of one 
of those pieces. It's a day coat and you can

841.text:
perhaps just make out the very meticulous 
seaming on the back of the coat.

846.text:
And in the gallery we've been able to open up 
one of her suit jackets and lay it flat so that you

852.text:
can see the lining is as impeccably tailored at 
the exterior. Maria Grimaldi did not have a

860.text:
designer label but she did have a maker's mark. 
It's a kind of spray of flowers that she stitched

865.text:
into the waistbands of some of her clothes. And 
it was a very modest affair. But we also have

872.text:
in addition to Maria Grimaldi's designs for Mrs. 
Abegg, a group of accessories that fill out the

879.text:
wardrobe. We then move on to a very different 
subject entirely. Looking back at that group of

889.text:
modest garments made by a dressmaker, it 
does give you a sense of the quality of the hand-

894.text:
made available across the country at the war's 
end and into the 1950s. But there was another

900.text:
phenomenon abrewing and that is the so-called 
Hollywood on the Tiber moment when so many

906.text:
Hollywood films were shot on location in Rome 
in their Cinecitta Studios. The Italian government

913.text:
actively encouraged the Hollywood producers to 
film there through subsidies and tax breaks.

919.text:
And so this helped to bring more and more 
productions to that city. Within the galleries

925.text:
you'll see some wonderful film clips from Roman 
Holiday and also War and Peace

931.text:
and La Dolce Vita. These images created a 
glamorous back drop against which Italian

938.text:
style developed. As well as the phenomenon of 
so many Hollywood celebrities descending on

944.text:
Rome and going shopping. So here you see a 
photograph of Audrey Hepburn shopping with

950.text:
Salvatore Ferragamo choosing her shoes. Many 
other celebrities of course came to Florence

956.text:
but also their holidays on the Amalfi Coast, their 
love affairs on and off set. This became the

961.text:
gossip column's favorite target. But the result 
was that so many images of Italian designers

970.text:
being worn by these Hollywood stars were 
spread around the world and it made a name for

976.text:
Italian style. Ava Gardner was one of the best 
clients for the so-called Sorelle Fontana, or

982.text:
Fontana Sisters, whose atelier was just behind 
the Spanish Steps in Rome, a very convenient

988.text:
stopping point for going shopping. This gown 
worn by Audrey Hepburn in the film

994.text:
War and Peace is in the exhibition and it was 
designed by the Roman couturier Gattinoni

999.text:
which is still in business today. And this is one 
of my favorite pieces in the exhibition, so I'll urge

1005.text:
you when you go into the galleries to stop and 
pay homage. It is a gown that was designed by

1010.text:
the Milanese couterier Mila Schon, and despite 
her name, she was Italian, based in Milan.

1016.text:
And she showed on the Sala Bianca catwalk for 
the first time in 1965 and by 1966 she was the

1024.text:
go-to designer for some of the best dressed 
women in the world. This gown was worn by

1029.text:
Princess Lee Radziwill, the sister of Jacqueline 
Kennedy, to Truman Capote's Black and White

1034.text:
Ball in 1966. And there you can see an image of 
her dancing with Truman. She's having

1040.text:
a marvelous time, I'm not so sure that he is. 
[Laughter] And what is remarkable to me,

1047.text:
aside from the fact that this gown is just drop 
dead glamorous, is the fact that we are in 1966

1054.text:
15 years after that first fashion show in Giorgini's 
house in Florence and we have a woman who is

1064.text:
known for her French couture wardrobe, 
choosing an Italian to dress her for the ball.

1068.text:
So look how far Italian fashion has come since 
that first sparcely attended show in Florence.

1076.text:
Here's a photo of the couple on the dance floor. 
You can just see her with her arm bent dancing

1082.text:
with her husband. And some other examples of 
contributions by designers at this time, including

1089.text:
the Palazzo Pyjamas by Galitzine. The First 
Lady Jacqueline Kennedy is known to have worn

1095.text:
a similar ensemble while entertaining in the 
White House. And of course the more typical

1100.text:
designs of Emilio Pucci, whose skiwear and 
beachwear really suited the American taste

1107.text:
but who also designed very fantastic sort of 
holiday wardrobes for the jet set.

1113.text:
His kaleidoscopic prints really struck a chord for 
summer wardrobes. This is our fabulous Vespa

1120.text:
which is in the exhibition. I couldn't do an 
exhibition on Italian style without a Vespa.

1124.text:
It was required. This is a piece of fantastic 
design that we sourced from a collector

1131.text:
in Britain who received it in bits, a pile of scrap, 
and lovingly restored it over several years.

1139.text:
And it's one of a few surviving examples that 
were first imported into Britain in 1949.

1145.text:
So it really is a remarkable surviving piece. We 
have this delightful broach as well.

1153.text:
Our only piece of jewlery in the exhibition, that 
was given to Elizabeth Taylor by Richard Burton.

1159.text:
And of course their love affair on the set of 
Cleopatra in Rome was notorious. But fueled by

1165.text:
jewlery purchases. In fact Richard Burton said of 
Elizabeth that the only word that she knew

1173.text:
in Italian was Bulgari. [Laughter] And when the 
exhibition came to London our sponsors

1179.text:
happened to be Bulgari so they were absolutely 
delighted with that quote so we used it often.

1184.text:
And we're not forgetting the men. We do have a 
group of beautifully tailored ensembles and suits

1193.text:
in this next portion of the gallery, with examples 
from design houses specializing both in

1199.text:
bespoke suits as well as ready to wear 
examples and it gives a sense of some of the

1205.text:
hallmarks of Italian menswear, particularly the 
bespoke suit which tends to in the case of this

1213.text:
firm, Rubinacci, it provides a really interesting 
counterpoint to the English tailoring tradition,

1219.text:
which until I started work on this project I was 
much more familiar with. The English jacket

1223.text:
tends to have quite a bit of padding, almost like 
armor. And as one tailor put it, it gently corrects

1231.text:
the defects of the wearer. [Laughter] The Italians 
take out that padding and as you probably know

1239.text:
from thinking about the Armani suit, which 
became the kind of uniform of the 90s, the

1245.text:
Italian suit jacket is often not only without 
padding but in the case of Rubinacci, because

1249.text:
of the Naples climate where they're based, they 
take out the lining of the jacket as well to give it

1255.text:
a more fluid drape. So these are some of the 
examples of tailoring on show. And then we

1262.text:
move through this very loose chronology into 
another portion of the exhibition, which is

1267.text:
dealing with the subject of Made in Italy. And of 
course from the late 70s onward, the Italian

1274.text:
fashion story moves on from the handmade, the 
bespoke, the couture, and that trace of the hand

1283.text:
to the factory. And when I say factory, I hope I'm 
not conjuring up images of mass fashion

1291.text:
and mass produced clothes because the Italian 
factory was particularly adept at making clothing

1296.text:
in multiples to a very high standard. For this 
reason, by the 1980s, even clothes that were

1304.text:
designed in Paris were probably made in Italy, 
such was the skill of the Italian factory.

1312.text:
And some of the designers that you'll see in this 
section are what you might expect to see

1319.text:
when you come to an exhibition about Italian 
fashion. Those big names, the Versaces

1324.text:
and Armanis as well as perhaps some that were 
once very well known but now slightly forgotten

1331.text:
like the house of Krizia, as you see here. This is 
one of my other favorite pieces in the exhibition.

1337.text:
I am a child of the 1980s and those shoulder 
pads speak to me. This is Gianni Versace

1344.text:
ensemble from 1985 and what's remarkable to 
me is that this is a piece that he gave the V&A

1352.text:
to represent his own legacy as a designer. He 
donated it the year after it was made and it

1357.text:
represents how he saw himself. And it uses 
some of the finest quality materials available.

1363.text:
Beautiful wools and leather, as well as including 
all the accessories, the hat, the jewlery, and the

1370.text:
shoes, and some of those pieces we've been 
able to show with the garment. The wool of the

1376.text:
jacket is made by a textile firm in Prato called  
Faliero Sarti and I went to that factory, they have

1384.text:
an archive, and Mr. Sarti remembers Versace 
coming to the factory himself to choose

1391.text:
the fabric. He didn't send an assistant, he didn't 
send his associate, he came on his own.

1396.text:
Spoke to Mr. Sarti and didn't like any of the 
houndstooth check Mr. Sarti offered.

1402.text:
He wanted something bigger and he wanted it in 
classic black and white. So those were made for

1407.text:
Mr. Versace to order. And we've shown the 
swatch from that conversation next to this group

1414.text:
in the gallery. Speaking of textiles, we also want 
to remember the fact that even though ready to

1422.text:
wear by the mid 80s had become the new 
fashion language, there were still Italian

1427.text:
designers like Gianfrano Ferre who were 
creating beautiful couture pieces, such as this

1433.text:
evening cape, which if you look it at very closely 
in the gallery, you'll see that the surface

1439.text:
embroidery comes out in a 3-dimensional, 
almost sculptural way. It's absolutely a tour de

1444.text:
force of couture technique. We've also got 
examples from the very witty Franco Moschino.

1452.text:
This yellow pages jacket is one of my favorites. 
And of course other examples from Versace,

1460.text:
as well as knitwear. Knitwear became one of the 
key drivers of Italian exports from the 1980s

1467.text:
onwards. And it includes examples from of 
course the house of Missoni and some wittier

1473.text:
examples from the house of Krizia. We also 
have a spotlight within the galleries on leather

1479.text:
and fur, two materials that are notoriously 
difficult to work with. There's a lot to say about

1485.text:
leather goods but I'll focus for the moment on fur, 
particularly the house of Fendi, which under the

1491.text:
direction of Karl Lagerfeld has made remarkable 
strides in all kinds of experiments with fur

1499.text:
making techniques. And you see an example 
here from the early 2000s which looks like wool

1504.text:
but in fact it's sheered mink. And each of those 
little shapes are individual pieces that have been

1511.text:
stitched to the one next to it in a kind of jigsaw 
puzzle technique. So we close in on the final

1521.text:
room of the gallery and in the sense that we're 
really coming up to the last decade of our story.

1529.text:
We started in the post-war period, meandered 
through the early decades of couture and the

1536.text:
handmade with a bit of bespoke tailoring thrown 
in and then we've quickly raced through what I

1543.text:
call the "go go" years of Italian fashion, the 
1980s, when Italian designers could do no wrong

1548.text:
and Made in Italy became the mark of style. So 
what's really been happening over the last

1553.text:
decade and a half? Well, it's had to do with 
Italian designers being at the forefront of

1560.text:
designers becoming mega brands, of fashion 
designers also becoming, in some cases, more

1568.text:
famous than the clients that they dress. And if 
you think of some of the major figures like

1573.text:
Miuccia Prada or Mr. Armani or the Dolce & 
Gabbana designers. You start to imagine that

1580.text:
these are individuals who now no longer just 
design clothes, they design an ever-expanding

1586.text:
universe of goods that includes bedding, hotel 
interiors, yacht interiors, all sorts of things that

1594.text:
a fashion designer a decade and a half ago 
perhaps would never have thought to turn their

1598.text:
hand to. And some of them become their design 
house's own best model. In particular, the case

1605.text:
of Tom Ford for Gucci, a dashingly handsome 
gentleman who often was photographed wearing

1612.text:
the Gucci clothes when he was at the helm. And 
of course his work with fashion photographers

1618.text:
and advertisements such as this on the screen 
helped to promote Gucci and turn the brand

1624.text:
around in a really dramatic way. This is a portion 
of the exhibition where you'll also see some

1629.text:
familiar names. Of course Miuccia Prada is chief 
among them and we have not just garments

1634.text:
but also accessories because of course bags 
and shoes are now today are now the driver of

1639.text:
the big brands, that's wear they make their 
money and that's where they focus a lot of their

1643.text:
efforts. And this is an example of that, at the 
house of Fendi and their so-called Baguette Bag

1649.text:
has become a collector's item. Now each year, 
each season rendered in a variety of colors and

1655.text:
shapes and materials, but always in a different 
iteration each season to give the wearer

1662.text:
a reason to buy that next Fendi bag. Lots of 
sparkle on show for Nashville. We have some

1670.text:
wonderful accessories in this section, including 
these boots by Dolce & Gabbana, and bags

1676.text:
and other shoe designs for you to enjoy. I also 
wanted to ensure that in addition to the names

1684.text:
that you will expect to see, there are some 
newcomers. This is a designer named Fausto

1689.text:
Puglisi, who has only been designing for about 5
